Sutro Baths.what: The Sutro Baths was a large, privately owned public saltwater swimming pool complex in the Lands End area of the Outer Richmond District in western San Francisco, California. Built in 1896, it is located near the Cliff House, Seal Rocks, and Sutro Heights Park. Only the ruins remain as part of the Lands End park. Time depends on how much you want to hike around Lands End.
Sutro Baths.why: For great views of the Pacific Ocean, and a hike that is not as busy as most of San Francisco. Lands End is used more by locals than by tourists.

Angel Island.what: Taking the ferry over and back is part of the experience, but does add a lot of time. Take a picnic lunch if you want to spend the day.
Angel Island.why: Because it is a fascinating park with amazing views of San Francisco.

Winchester Mystery House.what: Sara Winchester was a troubled heiress who heard spirits. To keep the spirits happy, she continuously added to her home on Winchester Avenue in San Jose, California. You can take a variety of tours.
Winchester Mystery House.why: Because it is weird and spooky fun.

Monterey Bay Aquarium.what: An aquarium, research station, and teaching institution that is just a short distance from the Pacific Monterey Canyon. Sea otters and harbor seals can be seen in and around the aquarium, along with a lot of fish. One of the best exhibits is a large variety of living jellyfish. Outdoors can include whale sightings as well.
Monterey Bay Aquarium.why: To enjoy the gift that Dave Packard gave his daughter Julie when she became a marine biologist!

Asian Art Museum.what: The Asian Art Museum contains one of the most extensive collections of Asian art in the world, with more than 18,000 works in its permanent collection.  In particular, the Chinese collection, considered to be the best outside of China itself, is a point of pride. That section reveals jade carvings, Buddhist sculptures, decorative ceramics, ritual bronzes, and more.
Asian Art Museum.why: To see amazing artifacts and artworks, far above any collection outside Asia!

De Young Museum.what: Located in the middle of Golden Gate Park, this 125-year-old museum specializes in art from America, Africa, Oceania, and the Americas. In recent years, it’s become particularly known for its sprawling costume exhibits, from contemporary Muslim fashion to the contemporary designer Oscar de la Renta. The permanent collection spans the gamut from gowns, paintings, and textiles to ancient artifacts.
De Young Museum.why: Don’t miss the Hamon observation tower on the 9th floor: the stunning, glass-encased space overlooks all of Golden Gate Park, downtown San Francisco, the Bay, and the Marin headlands.

Beach Blanket Babylon Revue.what: Wacky, saucy, and uniquely San Franciscan Beach Blanket Babylon claims the title of longest running musical revue in theater history. Its pun-laden send-ups of a shifting array of public figures, pop icons and dubious celebrities are loosely tied together under the auspices of a Snow White tale, but really this is just a vehicle to poke fun at everyone from Kim Kardashian and Hillary Clinton to the British Royal Family and Lady Gaga—all while sporting hats the size of small zeppelins.
Beach Blanket Babylon Revue.why: why see this? For the hats!

Cable Cars.what: Hop aboard for views of Nob Hill, Fisherman’s Wharf, Russian Hill and the Bay. Make a stop-over at the Cable Car Museum at Mason and Washington streets to see the giant wheels turning the underground cables that power the cars. The Powell-Hyde line runs from the huge turnaround near Market and Powell, and goes to Fisherman's Wharf near Ghirardelli Square. Insider tip: don't start from one of the turnarounds: instead walk a few blocks down the line, and wave down the cable car there. The lines at the turnarounds can be over an hour long, but there is no line at the middle stops.
Cable Cars.why: Dating from the late 1800s, a ride on one of the three remaining cable car lines is still a classic San Francisco treat and a National Historic Landmark.

Union Square.what: Union Square is a public plaza bordered by Geary, Powell, Post and Union Square has one of the largest collections of department stores, upscale boutiques, gift shops, art galleries, and beauty salons in the United States, making ita major tourist destination  Grand hotels and small inns, as well as repertory, off-Broadway, and single-act theaters also contribute to the area's dynamic, 24-hour character. Stockton Streets. "Union Square" also refers to the central shopping, hotel, and theater district that surrounds the plaza for several blocks.
Union Square.why: Visit the Dewey Monument at the center of Union Square. It is a statue of Nike, the ancient Greek Goddess of Victory.
